eUo6c7-9X9gU72I5MWWMuw.text: Great, authentic Italian restaurant in Shoreditch. The place is warm, decorated with taste, not too big, and the service friendly. Above all, food's great, with a menu that really follows seasonal ingredients. Will keep going back!

idKm36Oy61DXLi5aaZPvew.text: Came last night after only ever coming at lunchtime and having great food and service every-time!Simple well cooked Italian food normallyLast night I was really disappointedEvening vibe/ menu totally different though and was disappointedBest thing about my meal was the great salad as always.Not that anything was awful or badly cooked-(Pasta as always was nicely made) but just nothing special and all a bit over the top/ fussyRicotta starter was daft- a couple of slivers of what's probably great salami in proper slices and not much else but some odd sausage crumbsAgain- Melon/Ham nice but 'spicy avocado'?I've had great Risotto/Ravioli for lunch before, had some great Gorgonzola and Walnut Pasta too but all mains far too fussy and trying to be sophisticated... Not very Italian really last nightSugo also odd tastingOther half is Sardinian and was taking him out for a romantic dinner....Think he thought I was making it up when I said food was fantastic....Final really annoying thing was the 'this is what different pasta types are' spiel at the table.....If once wasn't bad enough we had to hear it 3 more times for tables to left of us.......It's a bit Leicester Sq tourist patter......You are a classy restaurant with great bread, good chefs , nice service and a great daytime vibe....So a shame the evening felt overpriced, overdone and a bit OTTIt wasn't awful enough to complain however so just muttered 'ok' when asked......Just wanted to be honest

6jDxVrwtQqWB28H2tQLsxQ.text: If you love Italian food and are looking for something authentic, delicious and honestly priced, steer well clear of this place. It might be an OK bet for a date you're trying to impress, but make sure they have no Italian relations.As a real lover of authentic Italian food I was really disappointed with this place. I think the best way to sum it up would be all style and no substance. The restaurant itself is beautifully decorated, and a lot of work has obviously been put into the look and feel of the interior (though investing in some air conditioning might be a good tip, as it was really quite unpleasantly hot inside when I ate there with a friend on a July evening). However, the food itself just didn't stand up. For these (extortionate) prices, I expect something really special, but as anyone who as eaten at an authentic Italian will tell you, it's possible to get much better food at a fraction of these prices elsewhere. The starter of scamorza and sausage bruschetta was fine  (but not exceptional. And how wrong can you go with cheese on bread?) but the amatriciana was a real disappointment. I like my food spicy, but this sauce was way too hot and totally unbalanced, completely drowning any hint of pecorino or guanciale (though there was barely any of this to be found). It's usually my favourite pasta dish, so I was really disappointed.Service was also highly erratic  for example, we had been pouring our own wine and water all evening, but somewhere near the end of the meal a waitress suddenly appeared and filled our glasses for us, which was more of an annoyance as I had actually had enough by that point.I was also a bit irritated by the faddy and unnecessary practice of bringing up a board to display the different kinds of pasta on offer  who really needs to have the spaghetti or ravioli explained to them? The owners might to better to invest this time and energy into printing some menus that are more convenient to read than having a huge chalkboard dumped on your table.

x8-RWMSckYB8W7WMENgOqw.text: every bite is handcrafted and delectable. definitely book ahead. unlike most places the tables downstairs are the best spots--practically chef's special tables bC of their proximity to the kitchen but  separated enough for a comfortable dining experience. the burrata is ridiculously sumptuous and the fresh cream tiramisu is out of this world. we ordered it, devoured it, and then ordered another.

XufhrS-bIB0RpgAJUbPMpg.text: Dropped in for lunch .Great no frills service and good people.Friendly in a way that lots of London has forgotten.Fantastic food.i am back in London shortly and will definitely drop in

XGNn7SWgSgx0tqvKgRx1QQ.text: Ummm, can I please move in here? Seriously. I won't take up much room and I will eat the offerings of meats and cheeses and even let people share the space. Please....Fred J nailed it with her 5 star take on this place and seeing as how I was with her when she tried it, I couldn't agree more. It is charming to the umpteenth degree. Totally approachable, friendly and warm. The upstairs instantly stirs up your appetite and the downstairs makes you wanna call up your girlfriends and have a gossipy little pow wow in someone's cozy little Italian living room.Definitely a must stop in Shoreditch! Trust.

5Y08noozSt0iWbM27tidCA.text: This is the perfect lunch spot for eat in or take away.  Rather than Pret or Eat, this place is an authentic Italian bottega with fresh veg, cheese and breads everyday. Their sandwiches are to die for, and are only 3.50 and can be freshly made in minutes.  I'd say it's as close to simple Italian foods as it gets, and the staff is lovely and there is always a new salad or side plate to try.  Perfect espressos and lattes as well.  No breakfast other than sweet pastries.  Good anti-pasta platters; it is apparently a popular dinner spot in the neighborhood too, but I have only tried it for lunch.

oKL2-l4m5ASyDGUaYY_FeA.text: I second Stephy S.  -  I want to move in here.Small, cozy, beautiful, delicious, kind, fresh, amazing. Staff are so friendly and inviting. They brought over a chalk board with a list of 4 or 5 pasta dishes for the day and all sounded incredible. I chose the orecchiette with broccoli, olives and tomatoes. It was just perfect. They pile olive oil, balsamic vinegar, fresh pepper and fresh Parmesan on your table with a giant basket of bread. This is me in heaven.We were probably in there for a couple of hours and they never pressured us to hurry up or move on, just smiled and let us be. Between the ambiance and beautiful food, it was one of the nicest lunches I've ever had in London, hands down!

RMPbnY7U_MsfR0Y49OLCZw.text: Well, this place might got it going on as a deli, but it needs some work as an evening restaurant.I so wanted to go here after walking by one night and seeing these great windows and small tables and a chalkboard out front with amazing Italian delicacies carefully written out.Trying to make a reservation though was tough.  I called 4 or 5 times during that day, but there is no answering machine and if no one picks up you just need to call back.  Finally I got them to answer....They have two bottles of red available and a lovely menu covering antipastis, salads, pastas and meats all at  reasonable prices.  We started with a meat and cheese plate for 2 which took them forever to prepare and had such an obscene amount of meat and cheese on it that we just had to take half of it home.  This is also the type of Italian style place where they won't bring you your second course until you tell them to....but they don't check on you either, so it was about 45 minutes of us nibbling on the meat and cheese before they asked us if we wanted our pastas.  Our pastas were delicious--homemade, but these huge bowls of pasta after all that meat and cheese--we barely made a dent which left no room for dessert and coffee.The owners/staff are sweet as can be, and the place is adorable--it has potential, but needs some work.  Also the Big Chill soundtrack was a bit odd.The downstairs is adorable with little couches--very cosy atmosphere.  But it really annoyed me that the bathroom had no toilet seat!  I will come back here to try it as a deli, but I'm going to give it a few more months until I go back to it as a restaurant.

BAbM6b84Z7OkOXJ7IcC8QA.text: Quite simply the best coffee in London! A proper Italian delight where you can either pop in for a coffee or spend half the day relaxing and sampling various elements of the light but utterly delicious quisine. Although a limited menu this could well be the best Italian outside of Italy!

gF_3Mx4TFTN27odgUx6E4w.text: This is the best Italian restaurant I've been to in London, and I've been to quite a few. Their ravioli is spectacular.

KZdereCmEZ3nDFf92Ea93A.text: I came here for a friend's birthday the other week. There was about 20 or so of us, so we were allocated the entire downstairs area just outside the kitchen.The restaurant itself is charming; it's got that lovely, traditional Italian vibe going for it, although the fact that there is only one toilet sent a bolt of panic through me as I entered. One toilet between 60 people? I don't like those odds.The food was great; we had a set menu to save everyone faffing about. It included a few courses of antipasti (mozzarella, ham, bread, oil etc.) two pasta courses (of which I was not able to partake) and then the option of dessert, although by then everyone was completely stuffed. The waitresses were pretty good, although they obviously struggled with serving all of us and the upstairs too.The main issue we found (apart from there only being one toilet - can you imagine that? One toilet? The war is over, people!) is that we came here on a hot day, and the room we were sat in was underground and had no ventilation or air conditioning. This made the vicinity rise to a temperature hotter than that dream I had where Olivier Giroud and Jamie Dornan gave me a bath. Everyone was sweating like mad and we kept rotating in turns to go outside and cool down. Obviously, being brought dish after dish of hot (yet delicious) Italian fare did nothing to cool us down.My thoughts are: if you're going to have a private dining facility in a restaurant, you should probably make sure that it's ventilated enough to keep diners comfortable and not sweating like Rolf Harris in the Old Bailey.

rlIrVcehL1GAtlMibtFwoA.text: Mmm.. It should deserve one star less if you are going to eat here once and then go forever, but if you are like me and work in the very same street, you'll understand why I gave it 4 stars!Italian cuisine, italian waitresses (everybody but one I think) and italian people in kitchen, good start!The place is just the exact replica of an italian "Trattoria",  a typical family-run restaurant with simple tables, simple food and lots of italian family love. Here of course you are in shoreditch, so even if the place would like to give you this impression, you'll always feel like something is missing.... but maybe it's just me!Menu is on the board (THIS is the reason why this place deserve one more star for usual visitors, nothing best than a place with different plates everyday!!), it's not really cheap (I can't really pay 10£ for a pasta, especially in a place where they want to make you feel at home) but still offers some variety, we have pasta, a salad, a soup, 2-3 meat/fish dishes and a vegeterian hot dish. Not bad considering they change it every day (well not everything, but at least 3!).Sincerely, I ate here different times and quality of food really depends on what you have: the meat is very good, nicely seasoned and tasty, pasta is not bad (well cooked but, for example, I can't accept pesto mixed with sour cream!), I suggest you not to have any "filled" thing (pasta or gnocchi), as they are VERY similar to Giovanni Rana's supermarket things... Obviously I'm not sure about it, but the taste is REALLY the same.................Of course you have to try coffee, as in every italian restaurant! here it's good, nothing special or surprising but a good spot where to have a nice espresso.In conclusion, if you live/work here in shoreditch, it's a good spot where to go because of the rolling menu, but if you are in shoreditch for one day...... look for something else!

nuIrtz7Qel_ZSGnBDn9DSg.text: 3.5This place is impossible to find. I wandered around the adjacent streets for nearly a half hour, asking taxi drivers, pedestrians and even a police officer and everyone seemed clueless. I suppose that makes it perfect for neighborhood residents who want to keep tourist riff-raff out of their favorite joint. As a person looking to dine, however, it's a bit frustrating. I know they can't control geography but... ugh.*Once you've arrived, things improve greatly. I like the vibe of the restaurant. It's intimate, has character and would be the perfect date spot. While I was there, there was a large group of folks whooping it up and having a laugh. I suppose the space lends itself to that. I maintain, though, I'd prefer BP as a date spot.Okay. You're sitting. Look to the walls. Thar be specials to eat. The menu is rather complete for such a small space but I was taken with the attention to detail the special board displayed. Thank goodness for the board. While the menu and service are both authentically Italian, that was a bit of a hardship for me. I had some difficulty understanding my server and was too embarrassed to ask him to repeat himself. Once settled upon a menu, it was time to eat. The burrata with truffle, for me, was more successful than the lamb ragout which, to my tastes, was rather sticky and a bit cold. Perhaps, though, I ordered poorly. It's a possibility given there were items on the regular menu that sounded fantastic. So, upon further reflection, maybe this is better as a group spot. Share some apps, indulge in some fantastic wines (every red we tried was fantastically robust) and laugh the night away.*I've heard whispers and rumors of a move. If it's to a location that's easier to find without gps and a police dog, I'm all for it.

fxXvNP6sQQLjyEUcqBDBkQ.text: Friendly American waitress was about the only positive in this place. Stay away if you appreciate good Italian food, the antipasti and pasta's were beyond bad. Reasonably priced for bad food though.

fdqhU2oRQEl3ns-3tKsgEA.text: Quick summary: terrible service, delicious pasta.I really wanted to love this place. In appearance it had everything I was looking for, cute ambiance, tucked away in East London with a cool but romantic vibe...I was wholly disappointed.To begin, there was no air conditioning and the place was BOILING. It wasn't even that hot outside so that was an initial bad sign. We sat down around 6:30 and they informed us the kitchen didn't open until 7, but offered us some wine or olives while we waited. No big deal. We decided to stay and sat near the window to try to catch the breeze, hoping for the best.We watched as one of the waitresses dropped a glass dish of pasta right in front of the door while everyone else stood around, went about their business, and left the glass shards in the middle of the entryway. When another customer came in, they walked him right over the broken shards of glass and we heard the crunch. It was comical.At 7 we ordered our food of a VERY overpriced salami plate and two pasta entrees. We waited nearly 45 minutes for the salami to come before asking about it. While we were waiting, the restaurant filled up and no less than two tables had already received their appetizers AND main courses. When we asked, they said they would check. A few minutes later they came back and said it was on its way and that they were just slicing the salami. Really? 45 minutes to slice salami? That's not even something that requires a kitchen. Theoretically we could have ordered that before 7pm. I call bullshit. And from that point on, our waitress seemed to make a point of ignoring us. We dealt with two others for the remaining duration of the night.On top of the ridiculous wait, the 20 quid for the selection was more than I would have paid for what it was. 3 salami selections, small slices of average brie, some melon, and some cold, poorly seasoned mushrooms. £12 would have been more reasonable.After more time waiting in the extremely loud restaurant (inside and out - there was a huge group of people drinking champagne on the street just outside the window where we sat) our entrees were delivered. The pasta dishes were both delicious, which is the only saving grace of this restaurant. The pasta was fresh, the sauces were hearty, and the portions were large.But that wasn't enough to outweigh the horrible service at this restaurant. To top it off, when I went to the bathroom there was no toilet paper in sight (i looked in every cabinet) and no hand soap. The room downstairs next to the bathroom was easily twice as hot as the upstairs. I can't believe people were actually sitting there. Extremely poor service, long wait times, the boiling hot temperature of the room, and the necessity to yell across the table to be heard could not be overlooked by the excellence of the pasta. Given the experience as a whole, we will NEVER return.

kD4TWrqk98h7pLCnROgbUw.text: Bottega Prelibato is a lovely little restaurant but I would not recommend it for a takeaway lunch. Prices seem to have increased compared to those noted by other reviews - cheapest sandwich I saw was £4.50 and I paid £5.50 for ham and lettuce. Not a very exciting sandwich (where's the cheese?!) and the foccacia was too salty. Overall for an Italian sandwich I'd say Gastronomica is still the best I've found. To sit and have lunch here will set you back around £10 so it wouldn't be an every day thing but might be nice if you're meeting a friend etc - portions looked generous and the service was friendly.

MR5RYNsHMY_h1LCJfTTX6A.text: I highly recommend this cozy and yummy Italian restaurant in the Shoreditch area. The place is small but very cute. We ate upstairs, but I think there is also seating downstairs. The menus is written on a chalkboard that the staff brings to your table side - nice added touch! The ingredients are fresh; everything is homemade. From the wine to main course everything is simply fantastic. The waiters/waitresses are friendly and attentive. Must check it out!

photos.caption: Photo of Bottega Prelibato - London, United Kingdom. Love the menu
Photo of Bottega Prelibato - London, United Kingdom. Interior, cute and cozy.
Photo of Bottega Prelibato - London, United Kingdom

YUTVvx8W92TctuV9Md3LHw.text: This Italian Restaurant is lovely! Their menu changes every day so that they can serve seasonal food. The waitresses kindly explain their menu and translate it into English! They also have a little sample of each of the various different pastas being served that evening. The food was gorgeous and the atmosphere is lovely! Our waitress was so friendly and made us feel really welcomed! They also have a sister restaurant in Wapping which we hope to try soon!

vL4hzn4VAZ93i8-8akS-qQ.text: A lovely intimate Italian restaurant to go on a date or catch up with a friend. The wine selection proves to be a good one, while the food itself is absolutely delightful. The prices are fair for such delicious and fresh dishes, making this a great choice for those who want to try something new in London. I completely recommend this restaurant to any and all.

o-Q95jCClUayrzMnMRgqgw.text: Visited here a few Saturdays ago, it was very pleasant.  There are no menus, just marked up blackboards that the waiters talk you through.  We shared a starter which was a kinf of deep fried cheese.  It was perhaps a bit overpriced for what it was, but then we were given extra bread without hesitation.  The pasta mian courses were delicious, extremely rich.  My wife's dish was actually a bit too rich/creamy for her so she left some of it.  Which I tried to finish!  £15 for a plate of pasta maybe sounds a bit steep but you get a substantial amount.

BKo1ejWjDTQ6TUwr-SHA8Q.text: A rotating menu, very attentive waiting staff, cozy atmosphere, and truly fresh pasta. What more could you ask for?The menu items are pricey and the starters are quite small. I wouldn't recommend sharing the starters as they are really not large enough to be shared. The pasta was amazingly fresh and I would definitely come back. It looked like it got quite busy in the later half of the evening even on a weekday night. I would come earlier to beat the rush!

Zlz3u8ZD9AbWcOaiMkrnFg.text: Just as good as Italy. I'm not kidding.My friend and I went for a romantic date for two to catch up on girly times, life and work over a bottle of Italian food and Italian wine, and she had heard of this tiny little restaurant in Hoxton, and she's lived in Italy before so I trust her judgement implicitly on these things!So this place doesn't actually do paper menus like 90% of the rest of the world! because it is changed daily, and the waitresses will explain the menu to you. Tip number 1- this place has massive portions. We went for two courses and it was crazy, I couldn't finish my pasta but I really wanted to. Our starters or Cechetti were melted cheesy aubergines and also scallops in a white sauce with raspberries, yeah raspberries. The thing with the scallops is that the elements individually aren't amazing, but together, it is a taste explosion, you got the buttery just cooked scallops, with a velvety sauce (that could have been warmer to be quite honest) and then a sharp tang of raspberries, it was unlike anything I've had and I loved it, and I wish that there were a tiny bit more raspberries to cut the amount of sauce that you get. The aubergines were Moreish. For our mains, we opted for pasta because I saw they really do special dishes that I don't really see in chain italian stores, like lamb Ragu with papadalle which is a Tuscan home dish really and I hadn't tried it since I visited Florence and it was something special. This really took me back to those happy times. We also tried the ravioli which was so well made but damn they they really stuff them! We couldn't even finish the pasta but I would totally go back. Also tip number 2- don't fill up on the free bread!So, this isn't cheap, service, food,wine and coffees came to around £75, but I would gladly recommend this as an authentic italian food experience!

2FghUG3jOwJNHjLqZeuDbg.text: I havent written about this place yet when its one of my favourite.Maybe deep down I wanted to keep it as a secret hehe!this place is a small restaurant and delicatessen, i've just been to dinner here (MANY TIMES) but  they also do good sandwich and salads at lunch.In a nutshell: delicious, FRESH food, bigquantities, good prices, nice italian service, cute and cosy setting.What more can you ask for?!The menu change daily, you can have the likes of burrata, mozza di buffala for starters (around 6-11GBP), fresh egg pasta (a lot of pasta names i never know - around 13-16GBP), home made cakes etc.Last time we went, none of the 4 of us managed to finish their pasta dish - and we were hungry!Nice wine tooA very important plus: they do aperitivo like in Italy!!#LOVE

TLKgGGSYJPb1WOb6eJ3Jaw.text: Theyalways take care in wrapping the foods to preserve the freshness of their foods.And the personnel are always able to give details such things and mentionproducts, you can't find it hard. Nice delis.

u2QY_FiIbRvMO7CAY7aQyA.text: Really great meal and fun unpretentious atmosphere. Caution as tables can be close together, but we met a wonderful young couple this way and had a ball chatting with them. Food was amazing. Especially the mushroom gnocchi.

EyDfW__KbnQHRnZGmYtjog.text: Fantastic hole-in-the-wall Italian restaurant. The menu is limited to a few different starters and pasta dishes. The ingredients were fresh and the pasta homemade. Everything was very well prepared and well worth the wait!The space is very small, which in my opinion makes it quite charming. I would avoid going there with a group larger than 4 people tho.The service was as good as it gets for London standards.

uxX8PSKx7b3CmgIKu0aVTg.text: Wow! Fantastic food. Authentic and the wonderful and personal service that feels like you are over for a meal with good friends.  The pasta was perfectly done, the red sauce on veal was really delicious. Pace yourself for salted caramel ice cream at the end it was so good I was eating despite being filled to the teeth.  My wife and I both loved it. The kids were less enthusiastic but even they were won over by the charm (and ice cream). Wine list was very good too, some great Italian choices.

mXsVOj7stNTND92rGhIlTw.text: I first went here March of last year with a wonderful friend and almost cried when I left London because I wanted to eat here everyday for the rest of my life. But as life would have it I came back to London for a quick 48 hour trip and made sure to eat here for at least one of my meals. Each evening is a different a menu, a few different starter choices, some pasta dishes and then some meat options. This last time I dove right into the Gnocchi and didn't regret my choice. The service is excellent, the place is adorable and the food is superb. Do yourself a favor and treat you a loved one here. Can't wait to come back...or maybe you all want to move to Oslo?

3AGSA7F_F9m8Rw7MBnltmQ.text: Great authentic Italian food. Try the truffle ravioli or the burrata platter, you won't be disappointed!

ctDOvWklBLPcQHDlLEKDYQ.text: There are a few things that those who know me closest know I adore with every ounce of my being. They are as follows:1. Justin Bieber2. Justin Bieber3. Tiny authentic unassuming restaurants/delicatessens4. Justin Bieber5. SunshineSince neither Justin Bieber nor sunshine have graced my presence of late, you'd be right to guess that this review of Bottega Prelibato falls into the tiny unassuming restaurant/deli category.With homemade pasta, small wooden tables, tea lights, sweaty meats and cheese, exposed brick, swoon-worthy atmosphere, and a precious hipster gallery downstairs, I could easily pull up a chair, a crossword or a complex Russian novel that doesn't resolve itself, and romantically fit right in. You're killing me softly, Bottega Prelibato, you really are. Add a sunny day and a shaggy hair cut and I'll demand Yelp adds another star!

RfR7tcvvkMtAl0X_vBGj9A.text: Food was deliciousService excellentAmbiance perfect. Love the brick, lights and music. Crowd isn't too loud eitherI recommend the scallops to start. They had an amazing flavor on top of the sweet potato mash and additional baby muscles.

PfenGvBmzAUXtmxeW-LZYw.text: Utter theatre. Tremendous food doubled with comedy of a service. Witnessed a waitress being sent home when the speed of the service was already in shambles. The establishment was happy to keep welcoming more and more customers that the kitchen can't handle making food for. We waited 45mins between courses, 35 between being asked if we wanted more drinks. Said drinks never arrived, and we were overcharged for them and an additional phantom round.The owner/manager was sympathetic to our treatment but made no offer to better it or make up for it in any way. £80+ for 2 down the drain...

ELtGGe8gFs6-IQJ0Qu39KQ.text: It is a great small little italian restaurant. They change their menu all the time so everytime I went I get excited of trying new things. Service is great too. I will say everything is quite big specially if you are ordering any pasta. I always gets really full if I order a starter and a main. I always think it is a great place to have dinner with a few friends and just enjoy the time. The only thing i will say is that because the menu is always hand-written on a mini blackboard, I sometimes find it hard to read.

J1ZhhPSwMcavrYt9pGpqJw.text: Best homemade Italian food I've had outside of Italy!  It was recommended to me by an Italian transplant who eats there at least once a week.  Will definitely be going back next time I'm in London.

uOt4JmIIgScLVVQ5qEUlbw.text: This place is OK. It's not great, but it's not terrible. The staff is a bit weird; they are scatter-brained and a bit slow but they are nice. The appetizers aren't anything special (I was hoping for more flavor from the courgette and pistachio) and the pasta is just OK. I had the mushroom and truffle oil pasta which was quite good but the other pastas ordered at the table were just OK. The menu you order from is awkward - it's a nice idea but the execution doesn't work. The menu is written on huge chalkboards that are temporarily placed at the end of the table. It's fine if the menus are not on your table because they don't take up space nor does anyone intrude on your conversation. Unfortunately the menus were temporarily on our table and not only are they physically distracting, the other patrons were leaning over into our space to view the menu.The restaurant itself is decorated well and has a nice feel to it and also is not too loud. But, I won't be back.

ujDt7ucQoCZg1lsZ29GDuQ.text: I'd definitely like to come back again as I feel that I didn't get the full experience last time. When I came here I only ordered a main meal but it was delicious! I had the seabass and crabmeat ravioli, it had so much flavour and wasn't drowned in sauce either. The staff were great, they came to tell us about the menu and provide information on the types of pasta used in each dish, very handy because my friend and I were going through the menu and wondering what some things were. It's quite a small, tightly packed restaurant, booking is recommended.

3U736zbd7qSQfvjzWmsycw.text: Bottega Prelibato is literally what my yelpy dreams are made of...After striking out at Tramshed (no reservation, joke's on us!) we peeked across Rivington and spied the wonderful unassuming, quaint, warm, beautiful Bottega Prelibato (herein referred to as "PL" going forward) --- we stopped in, were greeted by a very friendly (and very beautiful Italian!) man apologizing that they wouldn't have a table for another hour or so. Given hope and faith by the menu and his genuine nature (I truly believed he was really sorry there was no table available!) we agreed to come back in an hour or so and headed elsewhere for a drink. Good choice. We made our way back, and even though a table wasn't quite ready...I was so impressed with our host's good nature. He sprung to action, allowing us to have a glass of wine at the "bar" and offering us tastes to try things. A few minutes later and we were shown to our wood-topped table near the front window and all was well with the world. The big chalkboard menus were brought out (each table gets one!) with the day's specials (every day it changes!), bottle of water brought out, more wine...things going very well. We chose: Starters: Beef, portobello & chard (delicious), sausage & apple casserole (piping hot and absolutely fantastic and a light mixed salad they made special for us. They say they are "small portions, only for one person" but truly as far as starters go they are easily 5-6 bites each and very filling/good. Main Fresh Pasta: Rigatoni with Lam Ragu. Beautiful. Enough for leftovers, which were devoured this morning. Main Plate: Seabass (pan-fried) with spinach, and butter sage pumpkin gnocchi and balasamic reduction. Out of this world. The gnocchi was some of the best Iv'e had, literally bringing "pillow pasta" phrase to LIFE.Nightcappucino: dusted with chocolate, the perfect not-so-indulgent dessert. Regrets: That we didn't order the Truffle Burrata Platter with Parma Ham, olives and greens. The table next to us had it and it took all my restraint not to ask for a bite. Next time, it's on. Also we had no room left for dessert but that slab of tiramisu they were doling out was insane looking. All of this for about 80 quid + they don't AUTOMATICALLY add the service charge. But, you'll want to tip your ass right off folks, because the service is stellar, genuine and expedient and every staffer in the joint is fixed on making you feel at home. You'll happily spring your wallet to make them feel appreciated. We did, anyway. Brilliant place, so happy to have it in my area...couldn't scream it any further from the rooftops how great it is. And Britt X says they do a mean lunch as well (3.50 for a fresh sandwich, wha?) so Ill be back for that. *make a reservation.

photos.caption: Photo of Bottega Prelibato - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bottega Prelibato - London, United Kingdom. Scallops
Photo of Bottega Prelibato - London, United Kingdom. Interior

Bg_j27xbwIDLk2Juwh3OWw.text: One of my go to spot for Italian b/c it's intimate and authentic Italian ambiance. Love the chalk board menu and how the host goes through each dish. For first timers, it's a great way to intro the restaurant and make you wanting to keep coming...it worked for me! I think the starters are way more tastier than the mains. The jamon platter with burrata is amazing. Portion is great and tastes so fresh and scrumptious. It's really perfect in my opinion. The crab with asparagus is real nice and the egg w/portobello mushroom is delicious. I've had the mixed seafood pasta main and the shrimp pasta and it was ok. Not much flavor or wow factor like the starters. Tasted a bit bland. Also had the steak and also so so. Came out a bit dry and not too much flavor...maybe needed some salt upon cooking. If it got some more TLC...has potential...it's a shame for such a big portion of a steak not to be juicy, flavorful, and fully enjoyed. Must make a reservation. Staff are very friendly.

photos.caption: Photo of Bottega Prelibato - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bottega Prelibato - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bottega Prelibato - London, United Kingdom. Shrimp pasta main

DENB9k2UwTYBzsM2LmLQUA.text: First time eating here since it's a popular place so need to book ahead for a table.The restaurant is cosy and pleasantly rustic-urban inside and the staff were really friendly and helpful. Good cosy ambience as well.The different home made pastas were reviewed and the menu is on a board.I ordered stuffed courgette flowers for starters. It was nice enough but with a batter that was a tad doughy and surprisingly heavy so didn't have the lightness I was expecting.For mains I ordered a pasta with mushrooms and truffle oil. It was OK but the truffle oil flavour   was too overpowering and the dish was quite oily. My companions pastas (lamb ragu) and mixed pesto, tomato and mozarella were also noted to be OK but not too exciting. The pesto / mozarella dish in particular wasn't balanced and the melting cheese sticking the pasta together and thick pesto and tomato made for a heavy dish both in texture and flavour. The lamb ragu was less ragu and more cubes of lamb and the meat wasn't super tender as you might expect. I see others really rated this place much more highly so maybe our combination of choices from the menu wasn't the best one. I would be interested to visit again though.Overall 3 stars from me for food, service and value.

72aMmap9Yooc5WZDaY43xQ.text: Cool spot that makes their own pasta daily. It was fun to see all the different types of noodles before ordering.

photos.caption: Photo of Bottega Prelibato - London, United Kingdom. The menu, brought to your table
Photo of Bottega Prelibato - London, United Kingdom. The pastas of the day

CblI7dww84_dz9bxrlWJIQ.text: Have now been here twice in the space of 3 weeks. Great cosy atmosphere,  friendly staff and fantastic food at good value. I can't pretend to recall all the different types of pasta they had available,  and I'm no Italian but let's just say there's variety. Like true aficionados,  they come over to your table with a board of different pastas so you can see what you're getting - like cuts of steak at Gaucho but with pasta. And they're not afraid to make a recommendation.Each truffled gnocchi as satisfying as the last to sink your teeth into,  but my true favourite is the squid ink pasta with crab (whole claws of meat) and scallops. Just excellent. While £15 might seem expensive for a bowl of pasta,  this is no student food. The ingredients are high quality and you will leave stuffed.

photos.caption: Photo of Bottega Prelibato - London, United Kingdom. Beef carpaccio
Photo of Bottega Prelibato - London, United Kingdom. Squid stater
Photo of Bottega Prelibato - London, United Kingdom. Gnocchi with mushrooms and truffle oil

Vz9edyrzGoLkvDg36Kqtew.text: This is a very quaint little restaurant in Shoreditch. The place has only about 10 or so small tables, so if you want to try it out, make a booking first. They change their menu daily, so the menu is written on two pieces of large blackboards that are passed around to diners. There is a good selection of starters and the shared plate of prosciutto, burrata, olives etc. looked divine. But we didn't get that, we got the fried stuffed zucchini flowers. It is a typical Italian dish and, based on my previous experience, quite delicate. It is not like that here, as the flowers were covered in a thick pillow of flour and were actually quite doughy. I didn't enjoy it. They had 5 different pasta dishes and the waiter brought a board showing you the different types of pasta, which was quite helpful to me, as I have no clue. I ordered a dumpling filled with potato, cheese and orange sauce, because it was nothing like I have tried before, and my friend ordered pasta with mushroom and truffle sauce. Both dishes were excellent, but the problem was the portion was way too generous. I tried my best and still had 4 dumplings left over! Since my friend and I were there for a quick dinner, so we didn't go for their main dishes, which were one beef and one fish. Both looked quite handsome. I think the best way to eat here is to do family style and share a starter, pasta and a main.

photos.caption: Photo of Bottega Prelibato - London, United Kingdom

C_Z0i9SKwcz_nwmI6DG44A.text: I made a mental note to visit Bottega Prelibato after noticing it pre-Tramshed one evening.  I'm glad I came back.  As previously mentioned, the menu is written on blackboards and the waitress walks you through everything they have.  Yes, it's slightly overkill but she also came with a tray that had samples of all the different pastas they were serving that night so you knew what all the shapes were.  We started with the seafood platter which was a big bowl of prawns, mussels and clams cooked in a tomato white wine sauce.  Very simple but absolutely delicious.  Make sure you have extra bread to mop up the sauce.  It's the best part!Everyone had pasta.  The best was the veal ravioli.  Lovely fresh pasta in a tasty orange sage butter sauce.  We also had the vegetarian spinach ricotta ravioli which was yummy without being too heavy.  Portions were perfectly sized.  I was full without being stuffed!The decor gives the place really nice homely and cozy feel.  The waitstaff are also attentive, although one waitress slightly rushed us through our meal, but it's a small critique.  Definitely worth a visit.

gE_yfGiOG8G-6xk-5EZP-A.text: Excellent restaurant in the heart of Shoreditch that combines simple, delicious Italian food with a warm atmosphere and considerate service.  It feels like you're a bit continental eating in Bottega as the sounds from busy Rivington St are quieted upon arrival.The shared starters are a really nice option is in anything off the special board.  Don't hesitate to go.

s_6amKuK9yu_qdiB8iTU-w.text: The label of this place being a 'Coffee & Tea, Italian, Delis' is a little misleading.  i'm not sure what goes on their during the day, but if you go their after 7pm this is place would have to be one of the better dining experiences you can have in London.I always love a restaurant that changes their menu often, as it often gives some insight into the passion for cooking that goes on in the kitchen.  The fantastic host (cant remember her name) brings a chalk board menu to the table as well as some examples of different pastas before launching into a detailed description of what specials are in store for you that night based on the the "fresh ingredients the chef discovers at  the market that morning"For starters we shared the sea scallops with butternut puree and smoked salmon with goat's cheese.  Wow I've eaten allot of scallops in my life but these were like beautiful clouds of flavour!   For main courses we had the gnocchi, steak and seafood linguine.  The servings are huge! We all tasted each others food and everything was amazing.  i'm sure you could order anything blindfolded and still be able to polish of your entire plate. We washed it all down with a £20 bottle of chianti classico.    In the end we spent  about £30 each for dinner.....wow ill definitely be back!

tn4KdsQVnhYkLIEcE9XZDg.text: My favourite Italian in London hands down. The food is amazing, the portions are massive, the wine list is beautiful. I've been here with friends and on dates and the atmosphere suits both. It's cosy and full of Italian produce everywhere. All the staff are Italian and friendly, and you can ask them anything about the food and wine. Did I mention I'm Italian?I'm always looking for real Italian places, with real Italian ingredients, and not British places that make spaghetti with meatballs and pass it off as authentic Italian. Try the seafood, the pasta, the wine. They're all excellent. This place ticks all the boxes and I couldn't recommend it enough.

QGgvyzG-NldPFatpUBUhYg.text: Without any hesitation, I'm giving this restaurant a five stars. The atmosphere is welcoming and cosy. I felt very relaxed and it wasn't noisy. The food choice is very italian but not the typical sort of pasta (carbonara, frutti di mare, etc.) and other dishes. I had pumpkin gnocchis with mushrooms and truffle oil (£16) and they were just unbelievably delicious. Didn't want the plate to get empty. The choice of wine is very good. I would recommend the Montepucliano red wine. And the espresso is good and very reasonably priced (£1.50). They also have a good selection of starters which we didn't have.I definitely recommend this restaurant and would go again without hesitation.

a0AWakQXslUA4i5DQa9nsQ.text: Small intimate but lovely restaurant with a great cuisine. Starter were sharing plates which were charcuterie and some sort of vegetable matter my friends had. Nice and enjoyable. Perversely enough I opted for the Scottish Steak - I mean really in an Italian restaurant?! But I have to say it was excellent. Desserts were sublime as one can only expect from an Italian restaurant. All washed down with some quite reasonably priced Italian Chianti. Service was attentive but had some patchiness hence the loss of one star. I would definitely go back.  PS gluten free pasta options available! That's good btw.

gMDpBg1Nds5vQKFaYvTTyQ.text: Charming and cozy restaurant with FRESH pasta! Service was very friendly and fast upon arrival. They brought out the types of fresh pasta for the day and also explained every menu item on the chalkboard. We tried the spicy broccoli and chicken livers, lobster bisque with scallops, gorgonzola truffle raviolis, spicy seafood spaghetti, and the apple ricotta cake with salted caramel ice cream. The first course was great but when the pasta came out .my eyes bulged and mouth dropped to the ground. It looked and tasted amazing!!I was a bit disappointed as after we finished our meal we were waiting for the staff to discuss dessert with us. After about 20 minutes we flagged someone down and said what we wanted. The waitress made mental note but seemed to forget until i made eye contact with her about 10-15 minutes later. The restaurant was very busy so I get they were running around trying to service customers the best they could. Without this blip in service I definitely would have given this a 5 star review.No doubt the food is delicious and we will be back for more amazing food!!

photos.caption: Photo of Bottega Prelibato - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Bottega Prelibato - London, United Kingdom

DO2fLwgrwFcwVYnAKjWsqA.text: Unfortunately the service and food are pretty poor. Despite arriving on time, we were not seated for half an hour. And after finally reaching our table, we did not receive our menus and drinks for another 20 minutes. The food was average. The meatballs we had for a starter did not seem very Italian. While the lamb ragu was not really a ragu.
